Cool idea!

I had to try it on my eco project. I gave them 1 bit for the =
bias. 2 bits for the light angle, and 3 bits for each distance ray (6 rays =
total). They got 1 bit for the output thrust, and 1 bit for the output turn=
 angle.
So totally they have 21 inputs & 2 outputs. Each one just 1 bit.

T=
he summation, in the activation function neat.c:_genome_activate(), is repl=
aced with NAND. If a node has only one input the node acts like a NOT.
The =
gene weights has no impact on anything in this test.

for (n =3D 0, res =3D=
 1; n < nin; n++, op++)
 res =3D !(res && (*op->ptr =3D=3D 1));


In eco.c =
(LINE 30 - 39) one can experiment with how many bits each input & output ha=
s.

I uploaded eco-bnn.tar.gz, to the eco folder. It contains win exe + 3 p=
atches for the 0.6 src release.

They learn how to follow blue light, but i=
t takes longer. Train them on an empty map for faster sucess.

/Magnus

---=
 In neat@yahoogroups.com, "snapmedown" <snapmedown@...> wrote:
